................So, it's a Jefferies note. But bloody hell it's a bit of a chew on a Monday morning.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

If I understand it correctly -- and there are no guarantees here -- it's that Wood was a bolt-on acquisition machine and now it's not.

BE11:19am

Because it bought Amec, which was also a bolt-on acquisition machine.

A. Pseudonym What's with all the "pending" ? and yes the world's decided to plan a trip into the valley of the shadow of death again.
BE11:20am

And when you stick two M&A machines together with a tonne of debt to remove, management need to do things they've never really done before

11:21 am
BE11:21am

(@A. Pseudonym: "pending" is to stop people spamming the channel with, for example, eight comments about nothing much in as many minutes.)

BE11:22am

.... such as get debt under control and deliver organic growth.

Excel Developer Ghana is to issue a 60 yr bond after 30 yr fly off the shelves. (FT story) https://twitter.com/JacobWolinsky/status/1109101049783222273
BE11:22am

.... while sitting on a P&L that looks a bloody nightmare, because of x years of acquisitions.

nightingale20201 SOPH has come off 7% after JPM downgrade...any thought on SOPH's transparency (billing EBITDA disclosure, etc)...thanks
chopper bear why does mike want the debs ceo role so much ?
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Jefferies, if I understand it correctly -- and I reiterate there are no guarantees here -- is saying that the underlying position is worse than the headline and the divi's at risk if disposals slip.

Tom Dalgleish Did Ghana ever cash in that oil bonanza?
BE11:23am

At least, I think that's what it says. You give it a shot.

BE11:24am

WG reported that "strong operational cashflow has supported a reduction in net debt of $450m since completion of the acquisition of AFW [Oct 2017], and the payment of $231m in dividends in 2018". In Exhibit 3 & 4 we re-create the net debt bridge for both 2017 & 2018 and note that 91% of the $450m net debt reduction can be suggested to have come from AMFW UK Upstream disposal ($255m) plus the current drawn receivable facility ($154m). WG continues to see $200 - 300m of future disposals but timing appears less certain and with "known" cash exceptions of $100m we wonder about the unknowns.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

BE11:25am

Last year WG guided to "modest EBITA growth" for 2018 and delivered 5% y/y growth to $630m. This year WG guides to "growth in Adjusted EBITA inline with market expectations...of $716m" which suggests 14% y/y growth. Jefferies carry, including the impact of IFRS16 (+$30m) and including some impact for disposals (from Investment Services) more modest EBITA growth assumption, +8% to $679m. Last year WG gave no guidance for revenue growth but delivered +11% growth y/y ($10bn, equity method). This year WG guide to "revenue growth in the region of 5%" which, again assuming some disposals, Jefferies carries slightly lower at +4% y/y.

BE11:25am

While we outline guidance & our assumptions above, in the coming year WG will cease to use EBITA as its principal performance measure, moving instead to adjusted EBITDA (includes JV's) and reporting revenue on an equity accounted basis (excludes JV's). A further complication for like for like comparisons and for when viewing consensus is that IFRS16 accounting is expected to add $170m to adjusted EBITDA in 2019 and $30m to EBITA & operating profit. Jefferies estimates already include the IFRS16 adjustments. Exhibit 1 attempts to summarise these guidance points, accounting & performance measures and Jefferies estimate changes.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

With so many adjustments and new measurements, FY18 results did indeed appear "messy", a view compounded by a reported loss of $7.6m which was however less than 2017's $30m loss. It is our view that with all the changes mentioned above, reported earnings has to be a function of valuation as frankly it is one of the few consistent measures we have. Updating for all the variables to that bottom line (exceptionals lower than Jeff but interest & tax higher) increases our 2019 net income +14% to $74m but we are still materially below consensus profit of $193m for 2019.

BE11:26am

There's also a Redburn downgrade of Wood knocking around but I've not seen that yet.

undefined
11:26 am
BE11:27am

And speaking of rejigging your reporting metrics .....

BE11:27am

@nightingale20201 mentions Sophos.

Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 296.40, down 21.4 (-6.73%), High: 316.40, Low: 294.40, Volume: 620.42k
PBateman Any thoughts on Jeff saying AML needs more debt/equity to continue
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Seems they're abandoning Cash EBITDA guidance. And billings guidance.

BE11:28am

(@PBateman: that was last week, wasn't it?)

PBateman sorry i will pay attention better
TheoWelser Anything regarding Just Group's takeover rumours?
BE11:29am

And they seem to have communicated this via JPMorgan, which I think (but haven't checked) is house broker. It was certainly on the 2015 IPO.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Cash EBITDA has been controversial since the start. Management always set themselves an uphill battle when inventing their own preferred profit metrics.

BE11:31am

Here's what Caz says.

BE11:31am

By our understanding, Sophos may cease providing Billings and Cash EBITDA guidance, and shift to the more traditional Revenue and Operating Profit guidance. While we are disappointed that the company will no longer provide the outlook for billings, we also note that recent misses suggest visibility was limited and quarterly volatility was high, and thus the company is shifting to revenue guidance, where it can more reliably provide outlook.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

The company points out that:
1) Revenues and billings are more closely aligned today than they were a few
years ago, which is partly true because of the law of large numbers (new
business is a smaller percentage of the whole) and because billings growth has
slowed;
2) The company is changing the way it runs the business to match costs to
revenues instead of billings;
3) MSP ARR has been growing, and is now around $20m, or ~3% of total
revenues (which doesn’t get captured in billings).
4) The quarterly volatility in billings is difficult to predict, and thus the company
might be more accurate in guiding for just annual revenues and mid-term
revenue outlook (which would have an implied billings growth forecast).

A. M. (morning all)
BE11:32am

And in terms of the numbers .....

BE11:32am

We now model FY19 billings of
$746m, revenues of $687m and Cash EBITDA of $164m. We are
pushing through a slight reduction in billings growth (now 10% vs.
previous 12%) noting slower growth in the renewal base, plus
downgrades to Cash EBITDA in FY20 given the return of sales bonuses
that comes with the return to billings growth (so margins actually drop
in 2020, but recover into 2021). Likewise we reduce our Dec-19 price
target to 330p (from 340p) based on a 50/50 split of DCF valuation
(339p) and Cash EBITDA multiples (320p) vs. cybersecurity peers.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

So, that's that.

A. M. @Excel: what's their track record wrt defaults?

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 1.54, down 0.0451 (-2.84%), High: 1.79, Low: 1.10, Volume: 40.69m
11:38 am

I think my favourite bit of today's statement was .....

BE11:39am

Sports Direct does not consider House of Fraser to be a competitor of Debenhams. In any event, were Mr Ashley to become CEO of Debenhams he would, as previously announced, step down from his roles at Sports Direct.

Uh huh. House of Fraser, the large UK department store operator in rotting town centres, does not compete with Debenhams, the large UK department store operator in rotting town centres. Fair enough.

Anyway, Ashley's angle seems to be some kind of domination strategy for high street floorspace. Give everyone who can't wait in for delivery a pair of Lonsdale sweatpants.

BE11:45am

Anyway, read the statement yourself, I have nothing to add: https://www.invest...1903250700088015T/

BE11:48am

Jonathan Prichard of Peel Hunt is the best analyst here, IMO, so I'm going to massively overquote him.

IslandDweller @Flaneur. Agree about poor quality, but surely that's about failure of building control system, rather than the notion of conversion in itself
BE11:49am

Management’s decision to focus solely on the Naked side of the
business is not a complete surprise but the timing and the extent
of the strategic shift are eyebrow-raising. It is clear that storebased
retailing is not seen as the future here, and a buyer is being
sought for the whole of the Majestic side of the group. It’s
inevitable that stores will close, and if a taker of the chains as a
whole can’t be found then the shuttered number will be large.
The customer response to marketing continues to impress on the
Naked side, thus the increase in recruitment spend today, but
until there is more clarity on how the group is going to look in
two years’ time, it’s hard to be anything but an onlooker at this
stage. We do cut forecasts for the status quo group, based on the
higher spend at Naked and the likely malaise at Majestic. 20x
PE gives a target price of 230p, which doesn’t feel ungenerous.

Bonnemort Don't know how majestic survives
red @IslandDwelleryes this is cos the folks doing the building know the system better than those inspecting. its those who are at fault. those in charge as always to blame. you need to have top drawer inspectors not willing to budge on major issues.
BE11:50am

Who's going to buy wine warehouses right now?

Flaneur Corbyn will be in govt soon enough and he'll build houses on a huge scale - it guarantees him an electoral base for a generation.Anyone punting on converting their local debenhams into 'investment' properties needs their head rewired.
11:49 am
BE11:50am

Is Oddbins in or out of administration currently?

IMP.GLD I think we can guess
BE11:50am

cheeckychappy @BE - I do like drinking good wine!
RobinHood Anything on ISAT?
BE11:52am

Lay and Wheeler looks a decent business but it's a stupidly competitive space and the sale there won't move the dial.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Back to Peel Hunt.

BE11:52am

It’s always been clear that Naked was the favourite son here and with Majestic now excommunicated, all the focus will go on
building that brand. The latest news on Angel recruitment is upbeat and there is a positive link between a greater spend per customer and an even more enhanced quality of recruit. The US will be the focus but there remains growth in Australia and some in the UK, even if that market is reported to be very tough. Management is upping the marketing spend from the proposed £22m to £26m. That means our long-term numbers look underpinned but means we have to downgrade our short-term estimates. To a degree, our forecasts are irrelevant as the group won’t look like this soon, but we are shifting FY20 PBT estimates from £15m to £11m and the year after from £18m to £13.5m. It’s worth reflecting that our forecast for FY20 was £20m last June. The dividend will doubtless be cut.

Excel Developer @DJ : defeatism doesn't work in the housing market, if prices fall then lenders demand really high deposits so first time buyers get frozen out.
BE11:52am

With so much uncertainty here in terms of the shape of the group, and with forecasts falling again, it’s hard to be forthright to the upside. These actions are probably the right ones but there aren’t that many pennies of EPS to play with. Even a growth multiple doesn’t get the target price above the current share price.

chad_john What differentiates Naked from Laithwaites?
cheeckychappy @Excel Developer Is there something going on in the London housing market that I don't know about?
11:52 am
BE11:53am

Or for something more excitable, here's RBC.

chad_john Hopefully less spam from the former
BE11:53am

We continue to believe Naked Wines can drive a significant re-rating of the shares, positioned in the two fastest growing channels in the wine market. Our proprietary
US survey highlights Naked Wines as the number one website for selling wine among its target consumers, reflecting its overall superior proposition compared to peers as our research also reveals and 2x price advantage. Yet, the market values Naked Wines at over 60% discount to internet peers on EV/EBITDA, which we view as excessive.

Upaswellasdown Inmarsat total return since IPO of 2x vs S&P 500 of 8x
Punter @BE As a former customer of Naked, I was unimpressed by most of their wines but impressed by how hard they tried to stop me closing my account. I think customers swallow the story and imagine they are getting a better deal but IMO they are not.
11:58 am

Which makes it a take-private rather than a takeover. The impression here is that ISAT management is damn tired of explaining each quarter what happened to shipping trends and failing to get people excited about the loss leader of aviation installs.

Shinshin Wine feels like a perfect Amazon target, esp in Europe. Product is comepltely fungible so it's all about the lowest cost logistics. And they can do the tastings and fripperies in Whole Foods. Plus they have the market power to call say Jaboulet and offer to buy up an entire vintage.
Upaswellasdown @Punter - I have a very happy relationship with Virgin Wines, both the booze and the business
BE11:59am

Will Echostar (or Dish) come back in?

Excel Developer Lidl have a wine offer every Saturday. Just saying …
BE12:00pm

Well, Echostar and Inmsarsat now have the same market cap .....

Bluesky21 Not a fan of anyone selling alcohol - too many instances of supermarkets selling discounted alcohol to use up store space and pump up like-for-like sales, at the expense of profit margins
hornblower @Punter - I had the same with Naked, poor wine and they tried about 10 ways to make me continue
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Kiss goodbye to decent satellite services IMO. PE boys will milk this to death, like they do everything IMO.
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

..... and there's no real costs angle to a takeover. It's mostly about Charlie Ergen throwing a spanner into the Ligado moonshot.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Society so easily sells itself. Fools.
BE12:01pm

(I guess you can throw spanners into moonshots? That works as an analogy, right?)

Wangernum Laithwaites is active in the US with the subscription model.
Blank canvas Thanks BE for everything, especially Wood Group
Soundbuy Ditto with naked.......they do badger the hell out of you when you leave.......could drive a man to drink................
BE12:02pm

Going to chuck in some Olivetree here, as it seems the most sensible take I've read this morning.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

There were rumours of potential rekindled interest from Echostar just a few weeks ago and there was some speculation at the time that Echostar might be in a “pens down” agreement with the Panel. Note that Echostar has never been mentioned by Inmarsat in any of its communications with the market in the last week, showing that Inmarsat hasn’t seen anything itself in that regard. Now that a 2.7 announcement has come from the Private Equity group, Echostar would be released from any “pens down” commitment though – and it is interesting to see the Court General meetings scheduled reasonably early in the timeline from here. This perhaps, at the margin, suggests the PE Consortium is shaping its tactics around the concept of there being potential third party interest. On the flip side, most industry watchers seemed somewhat cynical about the ability for Echostar to compete for this asset. There are no real synergies for a strategic buyer over a Private Equity one, and Echostar shares have been weak in recent months. Its market cap is only $3.4bn – we discussed in last week’s note that the only real motivation for Echostar to bid would be to protect its sister company DISH (DISH US $14.6bn) from potential exposure to the Ligado situation. Eutelsat (ETL FP / EUR3.7bn) also briefly appeared as a potential bidder last summer – but has a similar lack of synergy potential and its shares got slammed as a result. It isn’t impossible that there is further third party interest for Inmarsat, but it is hard to find reasons to proactively rule any other party in as a potential interloper.

Ligado itself gets no mention today, and from talking around the situation last week it appears to be somewhat of a non-story. Inmarsat management have made it clear to all parties that the outcome to this story is binary and high risk, whilst also long dated still. Whereas there had been some talk of a CVR style structure to compensate target shareholders for any potential future upside, as last week wore on it became clear that this just wasn’t necessary – almost all relevant parties model this optionality at close to zero. Perhaps this is the angle DISH (via Echostar) has to compete, but it remains of tail probability only.

Airborne Cigar See also David Williams in the Observer yesterday on the current Aldi offering
